segments.text: by a contract from the Office of Naval Research.
So that has slipped into the CV, but it's not really, I was not an employee of ONR.
I was supported by them, but not an employee.
Well, what is the ONR's connection with the Duke Marine Lab?
Well, it'll be the same as it has with a number of other marine laboratories.
They have an umbrella contract involving about five of us.
bio-deterioration, studies on fouling organisms, boring organisms, physiology of shell deposition, things that are of interest to the Navy, and that's the only real official connection that we have.
Now, I noticed, though, that you also were attached to an old NR facility in London.
Okay, now that's legit.
I had an 18-month year leave of absence from Duke.
to serve as a so-called liaison scientist in oceanography and marine biology, ONR London.
And at that time, I was officially a civilian employee of the Department of the Navy.
And what exactly does a liaison officer in London, let's say, do in terms of advice to ONR?
Well, the primary objective was to visit as many marine oceanographic facilities as possible in Europe.
Talk with people about trends in research.

And then on your return to London, write up an article for what's known as European Scientific Notes, published monthly by the London office, distributed to over maybe 3,000 people in the United States.
And the articles that you write give an impression of the laboratories that you visit, the programs that are there, the facilities they have for research.
ever interest they may have on having American scientists work there.
Indications of an interest in cooperative research.
So it's to primarily keep the U.S. scientific community informed on trends in Europe.
Has there traditionally always been one American scientist attached to the ONR in London?
Oh, at the time I was there, there were
About 35.
About 35.
And 17 of them were civilians representing not just oceanography.
They go everything from anthropology to zoology.
And the other 17 were blue suitors, so-called, line Navy officers who had a more applied mission-oriented interest, but it was the same sort of thing.
They would visit the admiralty office or admiralty labs or French or Western German
the academic.
Has this been your primary connection with ONR, then your tour of duty, so to speak, in London?
Oh, yeah.
I've always had a reasonably close contact since the old days of Sid Gallop.
Sid was in charge of oceanic biology, ONR, Washington for many years, and I think got me started on my international interest.
Okay, that's the point I'm trying to move us to.
You're deeply involved all through your career with international organizations, and that seems to be the striking point about your career in terms of sitting in the Senate.
How do you explain that?
How did that happen?
Well, I remember the phone conversation.
In 1957, I received a formal invitation from Professor Crisp, now a fellow of the Royal Society,

then director of a small lab at Bangor, Wales, inviting me to present a paper at the 15th International Congress of Zoology in a section that was devoted to barnacles and celebrating the Darwin Centennial.
I was then just barely out of graduate school, and of course it came as quite a thrill, but the sad part of it was I didn't have a cent.
So, nothing ventured, nothing gained.
I called O&R Washington.
You can turn it off again.
Sure.
Didn't have any money.
Right.
What is happening is that you have no money and you said nothing ventured, nothing gained.
Right.
Which I mean, I assume you called O&R.
So I called Sid Gower, who I knew casually, and told him about the invitations.
and asked if it would be possible to get some financial support through ONR to permit me to participate.
And Sid indicated that under one primary condition, and that would be that I would not be permitted to go directly to London in return.
I would have to agree to visit at least one British marine laboratory.
which, of course, was ridiculous because I would have given my ITs to visit several.
So I reluctantly accepted the conditions, and he provided me with what was then known as Military Air Transportation Service travel.
And that got me started in the London meeting where I met all sorts of people from all over the world, visited the Scottish Marine Biological Laboratory afterwards in Oban.
Well, it's now in Oban.
It used to be in Millport.
Then went down to the big marine biological lab in Plymouth, met a lot of that crowd.
So when I came home, I had started to become familiar with a number of European scientists.
And it just seems to have continued, the contacts that I made then.
International Association of Biological Oceanographic Research.
YABO.
YABO.
What is that?
Well, there is a whole hierarchy of international associations.
I think it's ICSU, International Council of Scientific Unions, and under that umbrella you have international associations of virtually every discipline, one of which is YABO.
And this is a relatively recent effort to coordinate and improve communications
between people within any one discipline directly rather than having them go through some common larger framework.
Did this evolve out of your international experience, international cooperation?
Well, the organization itself evolved quite independently of me.
I had nothing to do with that, but presumably my position with it now is a direct result of my earlier involvement with international
Okay, what is your present position?

Right now, I'm the chairman of the U.S. group of YABO, and if things at the Edinburgh meetings progress the way I assume they will, I will wind up being secretary for YABO on a whole international base.
Obviously, you favor international cooperation.
Oh, very definitely.

Do you think that the new legislation and negotiations being worked on in terms of treaties and the underdeveloped countries claiming 200 and possibly other model limits will interfere with international cooperation?
Certainly it will, but the treaties are strictly political.
They're not scientific at all.
And we'll just take, as we always do, whatever's left.
Okay, and what will be the organization's opinion?
YOLO?
Yeah.
Will they try to negotiate?
I doubt that they'll have any say in the matter.
In other words, you're inclined to think then the agreements will be politically arrived at without any scientific input into it?
with very little scientific input.
And if it's a question of a political decision versus a scientific decision, it will always go political.
What effect do you think this will have on oceanography?
Will, for example, physical oceanography be limited by these decisions?
Physical and geological.
Because the only real

base for the whole treaty is to provide access to raw materials on the part of the country that thinks they own them uh do you think that that international organizations will play a role later on and then trying to renegotiate activities of let's say physical and geological oceanography
Oh, I'm sure that there will be a long progression, just as there has been already in the Law of the Sea discussions that will go on ad nauseum.
Now, how did you become connected with the NSF programs in India?
Through O&R London.
While I was there as a liaison scientist, the captain
wanted someone to go to Delhi for a meeting.
And somehow I fell into that slot.
So I went.
And then two months later, the captain wanted someone who was an expert on India to take three Washington VIPs on a tour of marine facilities in India.
Since I was the only member of the staff that had ever been anywhere in India, I was the expert.
And on that second tour, I met some number of Indian scientists and got to know them and communicated with them.
The whole thing evolved from that contact.
And when NSF wanted somebody to go over there for several things, they asked me if I would go.
Since I knew the people, I went.
Is marine biology making significant strides in that part of the world?
I wouldn't say significant, no.
Of course, it's been several years and the whole political climate there has changed since I was there.
It could, but there are some number of traditions that are going to have to be broken down before there's much really achieved.
In your opinion, will international cooperation, as you conceive of it, bring direct aid to underdeveloped countries?
such as India?
Only if the political climate of the country encourages it.
And the reason I qualify that, there has been a so-called PL-480 program in India for 20 years.
And the Indian politicians are very reluctant to give it free reign because of what they feel would be a threat to the economy plus a threat to their jurisdiction.
Now, who sponsors the PL-480 program?
Oh, it's like a piece of pie that is cut up by some number of different U.S. agencies.
EPA, NOAA, ONR, NSF, AID, the Congress.
Okay.
And I somehow or another have you contacted with, or you connected with the PL-480 program and the Smithsonian Institution at the same time.
Is that possible?
Oh yeah, because the Smithsonian has a piece of the pie.
Okay, and what was your relationship with the Smithsonian and PL-480?

Okay, the Smithsonian ran its PL-480 programs in a rather unique way, in that they set up an advisory committee of scientists, one for biological sciences, and I happened to serve on that committee for about three years.
And they insist that on any excess currency program, there must be a U.S. scientist as a counterpart to the scientist from that country.
So it's not just an effort to provide financial support to the scientist of some country, but it's to try to tie it to the U.S. scientific community.
but through my involvement with their biological advisory committee and visiting some number of their facilities and programs, I got rather knowledgeable.
And exactly what would you do in terms of your activities with PL-480?
Smithsonian.
We would review proposals that had been submitted by U.S. scientists, usually with the scientists from one of the other PL-480 countries, and then either
recommend that it be funded or recommend that it not be funded or recommend that it be modified and reconsidered.
Okay.
And in your opinion, what countries seem to work the best in the PL-480 program?
Well, the Yugoslavs had a very efficient program going.
Israel undoubtedly would be the top of the list.
But it was not really a, they had an advantage in that many of their scientists are trained in this country.
They speak English almost as well as they do their own language.
They have a lot of traditions and customs which are common to this country.
So they started out from a much closer working base than someone, say, in India would.
or would you venture to compare, for example, scientific programs overseas and scientific programs in the United States?
Yeah, it's possible.
If you start out with, say, West Germany, their level of science is very similar to ours.
England, depending on the discipline, now if we're talking about oceanography,
Some of their oceanographic programs are certainly equal to the better ones in this country.
Then you begin to get into a pretty gray area.
France, there's a lot more exception there.
Italy, there's still more exception.
The Scandinavian countries in certain specific subdivisions of the discipline, they're easily equal to us.
Others, they may not be.
Soviet Union, in certain specific areas, they are equal to us.
In others, they're about where we were in the early 30s.

And once you've covered those countries, and I can't speak to East Germany because I've never been there, but then you begin to get into a whole third tier of countries where they don't really have a very well-organized or a very modern oceanographic program.
is another story entirely.
Japan, very possibly in the realm of especially fisheries, would easily be equal to us, but in pure oceanography, no.

It has seemed, and I certainly can stand to be corrected on this, it has seemed that the ONR gave a great deal of direction to our beginnings as a country in oceanography, in formal oceanography after World War II.
Do you feel that ONR still gives that kind of direction?
Well, I couldn't agree more with your first statement.
There's no doubt in my mind that we owe the early development, the period of 45-50, the early development of oceanography almost exclusively to ONR.
Then, with the birth of NSF, some of the role of ONR was taken over.
And I'm sure others have commented that many of the staff who had been in ONR went with NSF.
And then, of course, later you had the birth of some number of other granting agencies, and AEC began to take over some minor role, now more major, in coastal oceanography.
Eventually you had NOAA.
But NOAA has never assumed any of the role that ONR had in the sense of support of oceanography through grants.
They've tried to do it in-house with varying degrees of success.
So the role has been diversified, and many of the things that ONR did in the 45-50 period are now done by other people, but not necessarily any more efficiently.
Do you think the diversification was a good thing?

Well, if you consider the emphasis which was put on ONR's support several years ago toward mission-oriented research, if that had happened without NSF being in existence, I think it would have been a real blow to basic oceanography.
But the fact that NSF was available to pick up some of the pieces lessened the impact
Diversification usually is pretty good if there's any real effort to coordinate and see to it that there's not too much duplication.
I want to return back to NSF in a second with the IDOE program.
But before I move you away from ONR, I want to ask you a series of specific questions that are almost random.
What is your connection with CG Bookout?
He was my major professor.
He and I have published together on 70 or 80 publications.
He was the director of this laboratory before I became director.
And he's a good friend.
Is it his influence that turns you toward the study of crustacean lava?
Certainly up to a point.
We started working together when I was a graduate student.
barnacle shell development.
And I became intrigued by the fact that you can't really study development of a shell unless you know the larval stages that contribute to the adult that grows the shell.
And that led to a study of a number of aspects of crustacean development.
So you could say yes.
But there were a number of other people who influenced that.
Good.
I was going to say, who else would you consider big, as we see in history, during the 1950s, shaping your career?
One name stands out perhaps above all, and that's Gunnar Thorsen, who was the man who developed the laboratory at Elsinore following the Second World War.
He was professor at Copenhagen.
I came to know him quite well.
He visited here some number of times, and his 47th publication on the larval development of Danish marine bottom invertebrates became a Bible for me when I was a graduate student.
And again, one of those crazy coincidences.
My first semester at Duke, I was required, as were all graduate students, to give a report to my peers on some research publication.
I thrashed around trying to find an appropriate one that I liked, and I couldn't.
So Bookie shoved Gunnar's tome at me and said, here, why don't you do this one?
So I did.
And the more I read it, the more intrigued I got.
I'm sure that Thorson was one of the primary motivating things.
Anyone else?
Well, there's quite a collection of people.
I would like to think that Dennis Crisp influenced my thinking along that line.
Although at that time he was not that actively involved in studies on larvae, he was in barnacles.
And Harold Barnes, who I guess is the second best-known British scientist in the realm of
Barnacle Research and with whom I attempted to work that year that I spent at Millport.
He influenced my thinking for better or for worse.
Okay, I have another problem with you too at Duke.
I have you listed as a marine zoologist and later as a research associate.
Well, I think this is some of the academia gibberish really.
Okay.
Apparently, you have to have a label of some sort.
And a research associate in the term that is used there meant that I was not an appointed faculty member.
I was working on soft money research grants for a long time.
And during that period, I would have been labeled as a research associate.
But you were still nevertheless working with crustaceans.
Oh, yes.
Okay.
I was afraid for a while you were and a while you weren't.
No, no.
never really deviated from the crustacean realm.
Okay, and crustacea, that's always been your interest as a marine biologist and oceanographer.
Has your interest always centered primarily around coastal activity?
Largely, although certain things have led me farther out into the ocean than others like this, the whole concept of distribution of larvae.
Have you made any international voyages with other countries?
Not really, no.
Now, when I have you becoming active in NSF, I am with you.
What were the goals of the International Decade of Exploration, the IDOE?
Oh, boy.
Well,
You mean the political goals or the scientific goals?
Scientific goals.
Well, presumably it was to improve our understanding of the oceans and contribute to a more efficient use of the natural resources therein in the interest of the welfare of mankind.
Was it oriented towards ecology in terms of scientific goals?
Well, now, when you say ecology, do you mean it in the scientific sense or in the public sense of environment?
I mean the public sense of environment.
I don't think so.
There are four subdivisions of IDOE, and almost all of them are oriented toward scientific objectives rather than environmental objectives.
Well, then what is the systematics and ecology program?
That's within NSF, but not within IDOE.
Right.
Okay.

This is a subdivision of NSF which receives and reviews and supports research programs by American scientists dealing with systematics and ecology of terrestrial, freshwater, or estuarine marine animals and plants.
But it has nothing to do with IDOE.
But it never had any connection with IDOE?
No.
Okay.
The IDOE is administered by a totally separate, discrete division of the National Science Foundation.
Well, what exactly was your role in the Systematics of Ecology program?
I've never had any.
Never had any.
I have you contacted with them for some reason.
Heaven only knows why.
